Phone: (617) 525-5300; Fax: (617) [PubMed ](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?cmd=search&db=pubmed&term=Weiner+H[au]&dispmax=50) | [Google Scholar Published September 1, 2005 - [ More info ](javascript:void(0);) Amyloid -peptide (A) appears to play a key pathogenic role in Alzheimer disease (AD). Immune therapy in mouse models of AD via A immunization or passive administration of A antibodies markedly reduces A levels and reverses behavioral impairment. However, a human trial of A immunization led to meningoencephalitis in some patients and was discontinued. Here we show that nasal vaccination with a proteosome-based adjuvant that is well tolerated in humans plus glatiramer acetate, an FDA-approved synthetic copolymer used to treat multiple sclerosis, potently decreases A plaques in an AD mouse model. This effect did not require the presence of antibody, as it was observed in B cell-deficient (Ig -null) mice. Vaccinated animals developed activated microglia that colocalized with A fibrils, and the extent of microglial activation correlated strongly with the decrease in A fibrils. Activation of microglia and clearing of A occurred with the adjuvant alone, although to a lesser degree. Our results identify a novel approach to immune therapy for AD that involves clearing of A through the utilization of compounds that have been safely tested on or are currently in use in humans. Alzheimer disease (AD) is the most common form of senile dementia, affecting more than 18 million people worldwide. With increased life expectancy, this number is expected to rise in the future. AD is characterized by widespread functional disturbance of the human brain. The classical neuropathological features are senile plaques, neurofibrillary tangles composed of paired helical filaments, and dystrophic neuritis. Compact senile plaques composed of amyloid -peptide (A) fibrils are associated with pathological changes in the surrounding brain neurons that lead to their death. A appears to play a key pathogenic role in AD ( [1](#B1)), and studies have connected the A plaque with formation of intracellular tau tangles, another neurotoxic feature of AD ( [2](#B2), [3](#B3)). A body of work has accumulated demonstrating that anti-A antibodies are effective in clearance of amyloid deposits in vitro and in amyloid precursor protein-Tg (APP-Tg) mice ( [4](#B4)- [10](#B10)). Solomon et al. showed in vitro that anti-A antibodies can lead to disaggregation of A fibrils, restoring A solubility and thus prevent neurotoxic effects on cell lines ( [11](#B11), [12](#B12)). Schenk et al. then demonstrated that parenteral immunization of APP-Tg mice with synthetic A in complete Freund adjuvant (CFA) markedly decreased the number and density of A deposits in the brain, with concomitant improvements in neuritic dystrophy and gliosis ( [4](#B4)). We observed A clearance repetitive mucosal administration of A peptide to Tg mice ( [5](#B5)). Subsequent studies demonstrated that clearance of A following immunization protected APP-Tg mice from developing memory deficits ( [6](#B6), [7](#B7)). Clearance of A and improvement of memory were also observed after passive administration of antibodies against A ( [9](#B9), [10](#B10)). The exact mechanism by which antibody reduces A deposition in animals is not known ( [13](#B13)). Possible [17](#B17)), and sequestration of circulating A resulting in an increased net efflux of A from brain and plasma ( [10](#B10)). The robust reduction in brain A burden in FcR-deficient, Tg2576 transgenic mice following A active immunization ( [18](#B18)) suggests that alternative mechanisms besides FcR-mediated clearance occur. A human trial of A immunization led to meningoencephalitis in some patients and was discontinued ( [19](#B19), [20](#B20)). Analysis of autopsy findings from an AD patient vaccinated parenterally with A 1-42 in QS-21 adjuvant demonstrated meningoencephalitis, infiltration of the brain by macrophages, and also an apparent reduction in amyloid deposits in certain regions of the neocortex ( [20](#B20)). Hock et al. ( [21](#B21)) reported that patients with brain-reactive anti-A antibodies had a significantly slower rate of cognitive decline than those that did not have brain-reactive anti-A antibodies. Based on the finding that some AD patients immunized with A developed meningoencephalitis ( [19](#B19)), which in some respects resembled EAE, we initiated experiments to determine whether A producing mice were more susceptible to EAE than their non-Tg littermates. During the course of investigating the induction of EAE in APP-Tg mice, we discovered that there was reduction of amyloid in the brain that occurred independently of anti-A antibodies. These results led to experiments demonstrating that nasal vaccination with a proteosome-based adjuvant that is well tolerated in humans ( [22](#B22)) plus glatiramer acetate (GA), an FDA-approved synthetic copolymer used to treat multiple sclerosis ( [23](#B23)), potently decreases plaques in an AD mouse model. Induction of EAE in APP-Tg mice results in a decrease of A levels in the brain. Based on the finding that some AD patients immunized with A developed meningoencephalitis ( [19](#B19)), which in some respects resembled EAE, we wished to determine whether A-producing mice were more susceptible to EAE than their non-Tg littermates. We immunized aged APP-Tg mice with CFA plus pertussis toxin (PT). As controls, APP-Tg mice were immunized with BSA or synthetic human A 1-40. We found that EAE developed to an identical degree in APP-Tg animals and non-Tg littermates (data not shown), and no EAE was observed in APP-Tg mice immunized with A 1-40 or BSA. Unexpectedly, when we examined the brains neuropathologically, we discovered that there was markedly less A deposition in mice that had developed EAE. We quantified the amount of staining for A fibrils in the hippocampus using thioflavin S staining and found a 92% reduction in the MOG-immunized mice versus controls (P < 0.001) and a 73% reduction compared with mice immunized with A 1-40 (P = 0.03; Table [1](#T1) and Figure [1](#F1)). We also quantified the total brain A content by ELISA and found a 94% reduction in A in MOG immunized animals compared with controls (P < 0.001) and an 86% reduction compared with A 1-40-immunized mice (P = 0.03; Table [1](#T1) and Figure [1](#F1)). No changes were observed in animals immunized with BSA in CFA plus PT. We thus used untreated and BSA-treated animals as controls. Effect of subcutaneous immunization on fibril A levels in the brain. To measure A fibrils, the left hemisphere of each mouse was cut into 14-m longitudinal sections and stained with thioflavin S. Multiple sections from the identical regions were examined for each treatment group. The quantification was performed in a blinded fashion using Imaging Research software from the NIH. P < 0.01, A versus control; P < 0.001, MOG, MOG B cell-deficient, and GA versus control. Effect of subcutaneous immunization on total and fibrillar A in the brains of J20 APP-Tg mice In order to determine whether the dramatic effect we observed was unique to MOG-induced EAE, we induced EAE with myelin proteolipid protein (PLP) peptide 139-151 in CFA plus PT. To induce EAE with PLP, we used aged APP-transgenic mice (Tg2576; average age 16 months) described by Hsiao et al. ( [25](#B25)), which are on a B6/SJL background and thus susceptible to PLP-induced EAE. We found a 76% reduction of thioflavin S staining for A fibrils (P < 0.002) and a 70% reduction in total brain A levels in animals with PLP-induced EAE (P < 0.02) versus controls (Table [2](#T2)). Our results with Tg2576 mice were similar to those obtained when we immunized J20 mice with MOG to induce EAE (Table [1](#T1)). These results demonstrate that our observation was not related to either the antigen used for EAE induction or the animal model of AD studied. Effect of PLP immunization on total and fibrillar A in the brains of Tg2576 APP-Tg mice A levels are reduced in B cell-deficient (Ig -null) mice with MOG-induced EAE. In previous studies involving mouse models of AD in which animals were immunized with A in CFA, anti-amyloid antibodies were shown to have a key role both in vitro ( [11](#B11), [12](#B12), [17](#B17)) and in vivo ( [4](#B4)- [9](#B9)) in reducing amyloid load. We therefore measured levels of antibodies against A in mice immunized with MOG or PLP peptides to determine whether any humoral cross-reactivity to A had occurred. As shown in Tables [1](#T1) and [2](#T2), we could not detect anti-A antibodies in animals immunized with MOG or PLP peptides. To definitively establish that antibodies were not playing a role in the EAE-induced clearance of A, we immunized aged J20 mice bred to B cell-deficient mice with MOG 35-55 in CFA. As shown in Table [1](#T1) and Figure [1](#F1), B cell-deficient APP-Tg mice showed a more than 90% reduction in amyloid load compared with untreated mice, as measured by either thioflavin S staining (P < 0.001) or ELISA for total brain A (P < 0.001). These results establish that the reduction of A following MOG immunization occurs by an antibody-independent mechanism. Clearance of A following immunization with GA. Because we were interested in the potential application of our findings to the treatment of AD in human subjects, we next addressed the question of whether we could immunize APP-Tg mice in a manner that would result in A clearance without causing EAE. To answer this question, we tested the effect of immunization of APP-Tg mice with GA, which is a random amino acid copolymer of alanine, lysine, glutamic acid, and tyrosine that is effective in suppression of EAE and is an approved and widely used treatment for relapsing forms of MS ( [23](#B23)). There is some evidence that GA may have cross-reactivity with myelin basic protein (MBP) ( [26](#B26)), although it has never been reported to induce EAE in animals, even when given with CFA. We thus investigated whether immunization of APP-Tg mice with GA in a fashion identical to that by which we induced EAE would reduce amyloid load in APP-Tg mice without inducing clinical disease. Mice were immunized with 100 g GA in CFA, and immediately thereafter and at 48 hours, they received an i.p. injection of 150 ng of PT. Fifty days after immunization, the brains were examined. We found that GA immunization led to a 92% reduction in thioflavin S staining for amyloid fibrils in the hippocampal region versus that in controls (P < 0.01) and a 70% reduction in total A levels (P < 0.01; Table [1](#T1) and Figure [1](#F1)). As expected, there was no clinical or neuropathological evidence of EAE in mice immunized with GA/CFA plus PT. Clearance of A by nasal vaccination of GA plus a proteosome-based adjuvant. Our laboratory has been interested in vaccination strategies for noninfectious diseases using the mucosal immune system, an approach that is less invasive than parenteral administration and that is clinically applicable ( [27](#B27)- [29](#B29)). We have previously demonstrated that nasal vaccination with A 1-40 peptide resulted in a 50-60% reduction in cerebral A burden in APP-Tg mice ( [5](#B5)). To investigate the effect of nasal vaccination with GA in a mouse model of AD, we treated animals with nasal GA alone or together with a mucosal adjuvant. For the latter, we used a proteosome-based mucosal adjuvant comprising purified outer membrane proteins of Neisseria meningitides and LPS (IVX-908; Protollin; ID Biomedical Corp.) that has been used safely in both humans ( [22](#B22)) and mice ( [30](#B30), [31](#B31)). APP-Tg mice received 4 nasal treatments the first week and then were boosted on a weekly basis for the next 5 weeks, after which neuropathological analysis was performed. As controls, APP-Tg mice were nasally treated with IVX-908 plus BSA, IVX-908 alone, or GA alone. We found that nasal administration of GA plus IVX-908 (GA+IVX-908) resulted in an 84% reduction in thioflavin S-positive fibrillar amyloid in the hippocampus compared with control (P < 0.001) and a 70% reduction compared with treatment with IVX-908 alone (P < 0.01; Table [3](#T3) and Figure [2](#F2)). In terms of total brain A levels, we observed a 73% reduction following nasal administration of GA+IVX-908 (P < 0.001) compared with control and a 45% reduction compared with treatment with IVX-908 alone (P < 0.002; Table [3](#T3) and Figure [2](#F2)). Nasal administration of GA alone did not affect A fibrils or total A levels in the brain (Table [3](#T3) and Figure [2](#F2)). Nasal administration of BSA plus IVX-908 or IVX-908 alone resulted in an approximately 50% reduction in total A levels (P < 0.02 vs. control), although there was no effect on fibrillar A staining. None of the animals developed clinical EAE. Effect of nasal immunization on fibril A levels in the brain. To measure A fibrils, the left hemisphere of each mouse was cut into 14-m longitudinal sections and stained with thioflavin S. Multiple sections from the identical regions were examined for each treatment group. The quantification was performed in a blinded fashion using Imaging Research software from the NIH. P < 0.001, GA+IVX-908 versus control; P < 0.001 versus GA. Effect of nasal immunization on total and fibrillar A in the brains of J20 APP-Tg mice Of note, there can be variability in the amount of amyloid deposition in the J20 strain depending on the age of the animal, especially in animals between the ages of 4 and 10 months ( [24](#B24)). Nonetheless, we studied animals of the J20 strain that were older than 11 months of age and did not observe substantial increases in A deposition linked to age in the cohort we studied (A deposition values as determined both by ELISA and thioflavin S staining for individual mice in each treatment group and controls are presented in Supplemental Tables 1-3; supplemental material available online with this article; doi:10.1172/JCI23241DS1). Our experience is consistent with the reports of other investigators who did not find a large increase in A levels in animals between the ages of 12 and 15 months ( [32](#B32)- [34](#B34)). Also, when we exactly age-matched our control group (13.3 months) with MOG-EAE animals and animals treated nasally with GA+IVX-908, we found a significant effect of treatment on A levels measured by 2 methods (P < 0.001; Supplemental Table 4). To definitively rule out an effect of age or sex and to test the effect of chronic administration of GA+IVX-908 given at an early stage of amyloid deposition, we tested age- and sex-matched littermates that received nasal treatment with GA+IVX-908 versus controls beginning at age 5 months. As shown in Figure [3](#F3), Table [4](#T4), and Supplemental Table 5, we found a highly significant reduction in the level of amyloid fibril (83%) in the brains of GA+IVX-908-treated mice versus control animals (P < 0.0001). Thus, the marked decrease in total A load we observed was related to treatment, not to the age or sex of the animals, and also occurred when treatment was begun at an earlier stage of amyloid deposition. To investigate the potential mechanisms by which A reduction occurred, we performed immunohistochemical analyses to assess microglial activation, T cell infiltration, and cytokine patterns in the brains of the immunized mice. We also investigated the types of cells in the hippocampus and their correlation with A fibrils. Previous studies have suggested that activated microglia may play an important role in clearing A in vivo ( [9](#B9), [20](#B20), [35](#B35)). To investigate the potential role of microglial activation in the A clearance we observed after subcutaneous or nasal immunization of APP-Tg mice, we stained the brains of mice with CD11b, a marker of activated microglia. As shown in Figures [4](#F4) and [5](#F5) and Table [5](#T5), immunostaining of the hippocampus revealed increased numbers of activated microglia following MOG immunization in APP-Tg mice compared with control mice (P < 0.02). The activated microglia we observed tended to colocalize with A plaques. Furthermore, increased levels of microglia activation were also observed in B cell-deficient mice (P < 0.001) (Table [5](#T5)). In addition, we found activated microglia surrounding the amyloid plaques following GA immunization (Figure [4](#F4)). We found no microglial activation in non-Tg littermates in any of the immunization protocols: parenterally with CFA/PT plus GA, nasally with GA+IVX-908 (see Figure [4](#F4)B), or nasally with IVX-908 alone. Although there is no known cross-reactivity between GA and A and we did not observe anti-A antibodies in either GA-treated or EAE animals, it is possible that immunization with GA+ IVX-908 could have resulted in priming of A-reactive T cells. The activation also occurred in animals with EAE, but was associated with leakage in the blood-brain barrier (BBB), as measured by staining for fibrinogen (Figure [7](#F7)). When we examined the cerebellum, we did not find increased activation of microglial staining in GA+IVX-908-treated animals, which suggests that the increased activation is restricted to areas with A deposition. Furthermore, no activation of microglia was observed anywhere in the brains of non-Tg littermates following GA+IVX-908 treatment, which further demonstrates that the increased activation is restricted to areas with A deposition (see Figure [4](#F4)B). To better understand the mechanism of the clearance we observed, we stained for CD68, which is highly expressed on activated macrophages from the periphery as opposed to brain microglia. As shown in Figure [8](#F8), we obtained higher staining for CD68 in animals with EAE compared with those treated with GA+IVX-908. This pattern of staining shows the migration of macrophages from the choroid plexus to the surrounding brain parenchyma including the cerebellum and cortex. With GA+IVX-908 treatment, there was increased expression of CD68, primarily in the choroid plexus space. This suggests that the CD11b+ cells responsible for clearance of A in animals with EAE migrate to the CNS from the periphery and are associated with neuronal toxicity, whereas the CD11b+ cells in GA+IVX-908-treated animals are primarily endogenous microglial cells and are associated with clearance of A without evidence of direct toxicity. As further support for this interpretation, we found that there was increased expression of CD68+ cells in the cerebellum of animals with EAE but not GA+IVX-908-treated or untreated animals (data not shown). Moreover, activated CD11b+ cells following GA+IVX-908 treatment were only found in regions where there was accumulation of amyloid. Furthermore, we examined BBB integrity by staining for the serum protein fibrinogen ( [36](#B36)). We found no damage to the integrity of the BBB in GA+IVX-908-treated mice in either the hippocampus or the olfactory bulb (Figures [6](#F6) and [7](#F7)). The GA+IVX-908-treated animals exhibited no changes in the behavior, as measured by body weight, eating habits, tail tone, or mobility, that indicated toxicity. Such changes were, however, observed in EAE animals. GA+IVX-980 treatment did not lead to mortality in any of the animals studied. Of note, in an ongoing, long-term experiment, we have observed no behavioral changes in animals that have been treated weekly with GA+IVX-908 for 8 months as described in Figure [3](#F3). In the present study, we investigated a novel immunotherapeutic approach for the reduction of A in a mouse model of AD. We found that induction of EAE in APP-Tg mice reduces amyloid load in the brain in an antibody-independent fashion. This effect could be reproduced without induction of EAE using GA given parenterally or nasally with an adjuvant. GA is an FDA-approved drug used for the treatment of relapsing-remitting MS. The mechanism of action of GA in MS appears to be related to its induction of T cells that secrete antiinflammatory cytokines that mediate bystander suppression in the CNS ( [26](#B26)). Furthermore, GA has been shown to be of benefit in experimental models of CNS trauma ( [37](#B37)), optic nerve injury ( [39](#B39)), and Parkinson disease ( [40](#B40)). The mechanism of action in these models is not known, although it may relate to the induction of T cells that release growth factors and/or IFN- ( [38](#B38)). In previous studies involving mouse models of AD in which animals were immunized with A in CFA, anti-amyloid antibodies were shown to have a key role both in vitro ( [11](#B11), [12](#B12), [17](#B17)) and in vivo ( amyloid load. The presence of anti-A antibodies and microglia-like cells that were immunopositive for amyloid has led to the speculation that clearance of A is the result of FcR-mediated phagocytosis by microglia of anti-A and A immune complexes. Since microglia are phagocytic cells, it has been suggested that microglia may function as plaque-attacking scavenger cells ( [41](#B41)). We believe that activation of microglia is the final common pathway for A clearance in our immunization experiments. It has been reported that increased expression of M-CSFR in mouse and human microglia accelerates phagocytosis of aggregated A, through increasing both expression of macrophage scavenger receptors and/or microglial expression of FcR ( [42](#B42)). As we observed robust clearance of A in B cell-deficient mice that also had increased staining for M-CSFR, the effects we observed are occurring via a non-Fc-mediated mechanism ( [43](#B43), [44](#B44)). Microglial activation by subcutaneous or nasal vaccination was correlated with increased numbers of T cells, which may play a role in promoting microglial activation, as there was a correlation between numbers of T cells and numbers of IFN--secreting cells. Previous studies have reported that TGF- may either increase or reduce A fibril formation in the APP-Tg mouse ( [45](#B45), [46](#B46)). We observed a reduction in TGF- expression in MOG- and GA+IVX-908-treated mice compared with controls. Furthermore, there was a strong correlation between a reduction in TGF- expression and the percentage of A fibril in the hippocampus region. In the case of EAE, we postulate that Th1-type myelin-reactive T cells are activated in the periphery by immunization with MOG or PLP plus CFA, and these T cells migrate to the brain, where they release IFN- and activate microglia. Encephalomyelitis and paralysis of animals results from damage to myelin and underlying axons. Immunization with BSA/CFA in the periphery did not lead to A clearance because BSA-specific Th1-type cells do not accumulate in the brain. Peripheral immunization with GA in CFA induces GA-specific T cells that have been shown in the EAE model to accumulate in the brain due to cross-reactivity with MBP ( [26](#B26)) and that, we hypothesize, accumulate in the brains of immunized APP-Tg animals. These T cells are then able to secrete IFN- and activate microglia but are unable to cause EAE because of altered affinity for MBP and the concomitant secretion of antiinflammatory cytokines ( [26](#B26)). Nasal administration of IVX-908 alone leads to some clearance of A, as it is able to activate microglia through its LPS effects. It was reported that injection of LPS into the hippocampus can cause clearance of A ( [47](#B47)). Nevertheless, IVX-908 alone did not clear A as efficiently as the combination of IVX-908 plus GA, which may be a stronger activator of T cells than LPS. Importantly, in non-Tg mice, no microglia activation was observed when GA was given parenterally with CFA or intranasally with IVX-908. A deposition leads to partial activation of microglia surrounding the plaque, and it appears that this activation is a prerequisite for microglia to be further activated by GA+IVX-908. It is possible that partial activation of microglia is associated with the expression of IFN- or Toll-like receptors that prime microglia for further activation by IVX-908 ( [35](#B35)). It was reported ( [48](#B48)) that Protollin could be stimulating the microglial cells both through LPS via TLR-4 and through Por B, which makes up 70% of the proteosome protein and is known to activate APCs via TLR-2. In previous studies ( [5](#B5)) in which we nasally administrated A peptide without an adjuvant, the mechanism of A clearance was postulated to be the induction of anti-A antibodies, as there was a correlation between antibody levels and A clearance. We also found a small number of cells that secreted IL-10 and TGF- in the brain. These types of cells are preferably induced following mucosal administration of antigen. In the present work, we immunized nasally using GA or parenterally using myelin antigens or GA in Th1-type adjuvants. The reduction in A levels in the present study was related to cellular mechanisms associated with IFN- in the brain and a reduction in the expression of the antiinflammatory cytokine TGF- (no changes were observed for IL-10). Thus, the mechanism of action leading to A clearance and the antigens used for nasal or parenteral immunization in the present study are quite distinct from those in our prior work. Moreover, even though there was clearance of A both in EAE and with GA+IVX-908 treatment, GA+IVX-908 treatment was not associated with the neuronal toxicity that was observed in EAE. Furthermore, there was an actual reduction in astrocytosis in the GA+IVX-908 treated animals compared with untreated control animals. In our studies, we did not measure cognitive function, though others have shown improvement in cognitive tasks in animals that have had a lowering of A levels ( [6](#B6), [7](#B7), [49](#B49)). When considering immune-based therapy for the treatment of AD, one must carefully consider the pros and cons of any such therapy, given the untoward side effects that occurred following immunization with A, a therapy designed to induce anti-A antibodies. A major question that arises regarding the antibody-independent strategy we have described is whether the induction of an inflammatory response in the brains of humans that includes a Th1 component will have untoward side effects ( [50](#B50)- [52](#B52)). It is postulated that the meningoencephalitis observed following A immunization was related to the induction of A-reactive T cells, and we have shown that there is increased T cell reactivity to A in elderly individuals ( [53](#B53)). In our animal studies, in which we induced EAE or nasally administered GA+IVX-908, we did not observe induction of anti-A antibodies or priming of anti-A T cells, though the latter remains a possibility. Inflammation, in itself, is not a specific hallmark of disease, and as a host defense mechanism, it may have beneficial effects, as we have demonstrated in our studies. Furthermore, inflammatory processes may differ. We observed a clear difference in the type of inflammation in EAE animals and those treated nasally with GA+IVX-908, even though both led to clearance of A. In EAE, there was breakdown of the BBB, no reduction in astrocytosis, evidence of neuronal death, and nitric oxide oxidative stress. None of these effects of inflammation was observed with nasal GA+IVX-908 treatment. We have demonstrated clearance of A in association with microglia activation. It should be pointed out that microglial activation can have both positive and negative effects ( [54](#B54)). Microglia represent a natural mechanism by which protein aggregates and debris can be removed from the brain, and there are reports that microglial activation following A immunization or stroke may lead to A clearance ( [20](#B20), [55](#B55)). In animal studies, Wyss-Coray and colleagues ( [32](#B32)) demonstrated that there is prominent neurodegeneration and increased plaque formation in the complement-inhibited AD mouse model, in which microglia were significantly less activated than in wild-type AD mice at the same age. This supports the concept that activated microglia have a beneficial role in decreasing amyloid load without causing major neurotoxicity in the AD mouse model. In an AD patient with stroke, Akiyama and McGeer ( [55](#B55)) reported a local reduction in senile plaques in a neocortical region affected by incomplete ischemia and suggested that their findings and those reported by Nicoll et al. ( [20](#B20)) could be related to phagocytosis of amyloid by highly reactive microglia. We have reported elevation of reactive microglia (CD11b+ cells) in ischemic area following stroke model in mouse ( [29](#B29)). Nonetheless, there could be dysfunction of microglia in AD ( [56](#B56)), and activation of microglia could lead to further damage.____ ___Although we observed clearance of amyloid fibrils in association with microglial activation, it should be kept in mind that there are differences in the biochemical and solubility characteristics between amyloid deposits in mice and humans ( [57](#B57)). Due to post-translational processes, amyloid peptides in humans are considerably more derivative and thus more insoluble. Despite the stroke example cited above, in humans there are instances of microglial reaction to amyloid, yet no apparent clearance as has been observed with AD patients that have had multiple bouts of inflammatory disease before they die. Thus, the controlled inflammatory stimuli we have produced in our mouse studies may not lead to significant clearance of amyloid in humans. Despite the fact that we did not observe toxicity in animals given GA+IVX-908, it must be pointed out that AD is a chronic disease, and chronic administration of GA+IVX-908 might cause side effects that we did not observe in our animal studies. Nonetheless, the fact that we observed a decrease in A load even after treatment for 6 weeks raises the possibility that clinical effects may be observed after a short period of therapy in humans. Furthermore, since we also found reduction of A without behavior changes in animals given GA+IVX-908 for 8 months, it is possible that chronic human therapy may be well tolerated. In summary, our results define a novel immune therapeutic approach for the treatment of AD that is antibody independent and is mediated by activated microglia. By combining an approved immunomodulatory drug used to treat MS with a nasal adjuvant, we were able to activate microglia and clear A with 2 compounds that have been used in humans with no toxicity; however, it should also be pointed out that although IVX-908 and GA have been given to humans without toxicity, they have not been tested given together. Given the potential side effects described above, they should be cautiously applied in human studies. Nonetheless, in view of studies showing that immune-mediated reduction of cerebral A leads to cognitive improvement in APP-Tg mice, our finding that a novel vaccination approach clears A in older Tg mice with no apparent toxicity in animals, provides a new avenue for immune therapy that might prove efficacious in the treatment of AD.
